title: Have you experienced an existential crisis? - Quora

response.answer_text: Unfortunately I can’t remember the date. It was a Sunday afternoon in 2014. To call this a “crisis” might be a bit overdramatic. It was more like a moment of clarity at the end of a long search — a moment that could have gone very badly. I’m 60 years old now. When I was 15, I started trying to understand the answer to “who am I?” — the basic existential question, right? So I spent over 40 years working that question, trying out many different disciplines and perspectives and studying what I could find on the topic (which is a lot: the world is full of viewpoints about this!) What I wanted was an absolute truth that I could trust: some moment where I would see myself in some sort of mirror that could not be denied or questioned. So I spent my life looking for that kind of mirror, really. That’s one way to frame the story, anyway. (I also lived of course — married several times, kids, a career… this search wasn’t in an ivory tower.) Then this Sunday afternoon came along, and I realized that the only way that I would ever have an absolute truth about my own being would be if I created that truth myself. My absolute commitment to the grounding and upholding of that truth is what would make it absolute, and nothing else could do that for me. I saw that the notion that this truth could be pre-existing so that it could be “discovered” was wrong, and I finally understood why it was wrong and what one could do about that. In the short space of a few days, a whole ton of questions got resolved for me: questions about values and meaning, questions about motivation and generosity and courage and vision and possibility. My whole perspective about myself and life underwent a transformation in the wake of this Sunday afternoon. Why did I say that this was a “crisis”? Because I think that the genesis of this realization was a kind of “coming to the end of the road” in terms of trying to locate that absolute truth by searching. Having searched everywhere and not found it, it would have been very easy to give up and collapse in frustration and despair. I think if you do that, then you maybe don’t notice the little gray door by the side of the road which has no flashing neon lights or reassuring label that makes claims of wisdom. If you just give up and collapse into despair and nihilism, then you don’t see that this uninteresting door leads to the solution: a human has the power to create the truth of their own authenticity, and that is what solves the puzzle — nothing else. The search for true self is just what you do because you don’t understand. When one gives up on the search because it’s not working, that’s a dangerous moment I think — it’s very easy to miss the recognition that “I can be my own ground of being.” That’s where nihilists come from, I think. A crisis like that, if you don’t resolve it correctly, is a real problem.

What is an example of an existential crisis? Anytime anyone questions their reality, what they see happening does not align with what they thought could happen in the world, that is the trigger of an Existential Crisis. An Existential Crisis causes an emotional shock to occur because the person realizes what they thought was “firm ground to base their world view” is in fact unstable and disappearing at that moment right before their eyes as they examine the situation, realizing what they thought to be true is not true at all. This is the nature of an Existential Crisis. Examples include: Devout Christian family breaks up when Dad announces he’s gay and moves in with his new lover. Wife and teenage kids all experience Existential Crisis, because from their world view Dad is abandoning the family, the church, and is willingly going to hell;Serious student with straight A’s simply cannot get an A in the class their future college career depends, throwing their imagined future life into question;Socially popular teen begins to see the toxic treatment of their set towards others, calling out their peers’ behavior, they are cast out of their popular set and now face other social sets poised to reject them for past bad behaviors;What to do about an Existential Crisis? Recognize them as an unbalanced emotional reaction to a self deception being revealed. It is a self deception because it is the individual’s responsibility to tell themselves the truth, even when painful. Any pain associated with the emotional shock accompanying this Existential Crisis serves to cement the memory as a mental milestone to remember the pain and the lesson that this specific instance of self deception caused this specific problem. As duel recognition of being in an Existential Crisis and recognition of the lesson being learned commits to memory, temper oneself to not over react. At that point in time step outside yourself and take some analytical notes. This serves to release an amount of the emotional energy and to re-center your awareness away from the immediate moment to a more timeless perspective, a perspective where you’ll have more control over your emotions, granting a clearer perspective of the situation and how to move forward.

Many. I suppose I have lost count really. Some of them were really dark, probably dangerous moments of my life and others were those moments of “oh no! I really am as stupid and insignificant as I have been told”. I’ve had quite a few life threatening situations occur, whilst going through alchohol and drug fuelled moments of existentialism. But I always survived in the most bizzare ways. I’m not cut out, to be cut out by my own crisis-ies apparently. I decided very early on in my life, that “plodding on”, eternally plodding on, was the only way to get to wherever it is that I am supposed to be going. I became a survivor, just because I am bloody minded. This does not mean that I am not still, occasionally dragged down by a new existential crisis. I haven’t had a good one for over a year now, which means progress, methinks. There are bound to be others in the pipeline, waiting for the unwary me, just when I think that I’m going okay, bang! I’ll be brought down so low that I can see up skirts. I’ll feel dirty and useless, a waste of time, a wastrel. I’ll lumber along in a haze of self loathing until I get so depressed that I will remember my mantra. It could always be worse, you asshole. And I’ll get up, and start pushing that rock up the hill again. Sisyphus and me have a lot in common, a lot more than I care to relate here. But if you want to have an idea, have a read of this wiki page. The Myth of Sisyphus - Wikipedia

All identity is someone clinging to a fixed or reinforced idea of themselves like armor. From this, we derive a sense of existence and context by assuming a false idea to be truth, and maintain it by reinforcing the places where it fails us through various denials and projections. ALL identity is constructed this way. When one’s armor breaks entirely, or substantial parts of it break, and more information, understanding and reality come through that don’t meet with those idealisms and other plates of armor; then you’ll likely have such a crisis. Indeed, such crises are endemic in Western society, simply because we refuse to teach anyone about themselves. We devalue it, and allow them to flee from crisis to crisis (or maintain the false armor we have given to them regarding materialism, consumerism, belief in media, the rightness of white people, etc.) that they often have a crisis without any way to really grow from it, or their crises are so trivial that despite their life change they really only re-invest back in the same system that created the problem they are experiencing now. It wasn’t always this way, and there are few teachers or mentors left. Everyone who was one before is assumed to be a pedophile or other deviant, so… let’s be scared of the solution, too… right? Oh, well, and anyone who asks us to be volunteering for difficulties is now an enemy as well, so even the crises that allow us to mature and shed our old skin have ALSO been disallowed at this point. You ARE allowed to do sports, so there is that. Video games and sports. Decent distractions, right? Just don’t try to grow TOO much from your participation in them, as you might discover more to yourself than society wants to allow… so be careful. Western society is constructed from absolute ignorance of ourselves and so existential crises will ALWAYS happen here. Everything that would create these crises is both produced at every turn, but also denied. It is also denied that they are valid, needed or useful in any way. The construction of an identity centred on the specific identity that society wants from you (consumerist, paranoid, fearful, productive: aka enslaved) is what is allowed. ONLY that. If you’re brown, white, whatever. Colors don’t matter. Class doesn’t matter. EVERYONE is a slave now. Trapped in the identity they call themselves. Don’t fall for any of this. You can still be free. The tools are all in your mind, or in the minds of people you can learn from, which still exist, like Neo in the Matrix. We still exist. Come find us.

Yeah. I think I had my first one when I was about 7–8 years old. I was super into this ‘Children’s Encyclopedia’ book which was basically a very, very abridged history of the human race. It detailed the rise of the Egyptians, the Romans, the Greeks, and more. Now, at some point while I was going through the book, I remember thinking, ‘What had happened to all these people I’m reading about? What happened to Columbus? What happened to Newton? What happened to everybody?’. I put down the book and thought for a bit about this enigma. And I just began to. Bawl. My. Eyes. Out. My mother picked me up and tried to comfort me, but I was inconsolable. I could only manage to blubber out a ‘and, and, and I’M gonna disappear, and YOU’RE gonna disappear, and PAPA’S gonna disappear’ to her before I was too far gone in my horror to even talk. At some point, I managed to stop crying, but a deep cynicism towards life was installed in me for a few days. I felt sullen and angry that I wasted any time on playing, or studying, or eating. Luckily, my memory was pretty shabby and I soon forgot all about my revelation. I promptly went back to annoying everybody around me with my squeals and enjoying foods far too fattening for a child.

I believe an “existential crisis” is fundamentally a point in your life where you have to decide … Is there a God who created me for some purpose or not… simple. If there is a God… now the question is how does God communicate that purpose to me? If I come up with a no-God belief I must “boldly create my own purpose”. Kierkegaard was a Christian and defined his existentialism within the paradigm of the Christian faith. So, his crisis came about from the dead faith of “nominalism” . He saw that Danish Lutheranism was just going through the motions. It lacked the vibrancy and life of an “existential faith”. He saw that he had to break free of his nominalism rooted in rationalism and take a “leap of faith” in the personally subjective. He really discovered the necessity of subjective faith or existential faith. One discovers in this crisis the need to break free from “the Formal Faith” into “a personal faith”… “my personal relationship with God”. Kierkegaard really is the forerunner of the modern day distinction between Christian “religion” and “personal relationship” regarding faith in God. In modern evangelicalism “religion” is a dirty word because it is seen to lack the “existential” aspect of “personal relationship”. Shift: I shift now to the existential atheism of Nietzsche, Satre and Camus - to name the biggies. Simply, if you don’t turn to a personal relationship (existential) with God, then you are on your own buddy! For some, this is a great relief and freedom from a common paradigmatic negative view of God. This is the view that God is 1) dictatorial, judgmental and punishing . Christianity in turn is man-made and an attempt of the religious to control the non-religious. You want to be free from something like that don’t you? … if it in deed is true! If the result of existential atheism is nihilism… true nihilism you will be stuck in the insanity of meaninglessness - constantly searching and jumping from one insight to the next, one “a-ha” season to the next. It gets old. You get no where because there is no where ultimately to go. However a happy existentialist is not a true nihilist at all. In fact they are really not an existentialist at all! A relatively happy existentialist is one who has really locked into a religion of some sort … a religious philosophy of life. The happy existentialist must lock into some kind of social fellowship… be a part of a body of like-minded believers… in something and something established and formal. Even a society of “existentialists”. Bottom line: The happy ending of an existential crisis is finding one’s part in an established whole… a human whole with friendship and fellowship. Adding my final bias… Jesus Christ is the penultimate existence… the Gospel “In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. He was with God in the beginning. Through Him all things were made, and without Him nothing was made that has been made. In Him was life, and that life was the light of men. The Light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it. “ John 1:1–5 “God intended that they would seek Him and perhaps reach out for Him and find Him, though He is not far from each one of us. ‘For in Him we live and move and have our being.’” Acts 17:27–28

It’s sad but my crisis came from someone else’s So One day, scrolling through my social media feeds whilst waiting for the bathroom to free up, fairly ordinary. Suddenly I come across an odd image, a napkin laminated. What’s so significant? A laminated napkin is something that’s basically lost all its purpose, it’s become perfect and cannot be ruined but it’s lost it’s purpose. I hit a blunt so to speak. My mind ran in circles and desperate to share I told mum sister, she was 6 and didn’t get it. I told mum, she laughed it off. I told some friends, they said wow. But it kept on running round in my mind. Napkin, purpose, laminated, purpose gone. But it’s purpose was so trivial maybe the trade off was good, but whaaattt?? After all this crisissing I hit something else, what’s my purpose, how would I lose my purpose, is perfection the loss of purpose?preservation or purpose, preservation or purpose, preservation or purpose, is preservation not the purpose? Is purpose preservation? Is this what it means to decay? To be redundant? I am still perhaps in that perpetual crisis for I haven’t figured out the answer.

One in which someone does not know where they came from, why they are here, and where they are going when they die. God, in the Holy Scriptures, gives us definitive answers beginning in the book of Genesis and throughout the Bible concerning these questions. Holy Scripture [Excerpt] God has carefully and individually made YOU, “fearfully and wonderfully.” (Psalm 139:14) So if He thought of us and created each of us so intentionally, we need to understand His purpose for the lives He has given us. God has an incredibly valuable task for you. You, in the situations of your life that He created uniquely for you, should carry out His will on earth, as it is done in heaven. God has prepared specific works for each of us to walk in. (Ephesians 2:10; Philippians 2:12-14) Perhaps one of the most beautiful and life-affirming passages in the Bible are the words of David in Psalm 139. “My frame was not hidden from you, when I was made in secret, and skillfully wrought in the lowest parts of the earth. Your eyes saw my substance, being yet unformed. And in Your book they all are written, the days fashioned for me, when as yet there were none of them.” Psalm 139:15-16. Jesus was with the Father as a master craftsman when He marked out the foundations of the earth. He rejoiced in all His inhabited world, but His delight was with the sons of men. (Proverbs 8:22-31) So when the time was right, Jesus took upon Himself the body of a man, born of Mary, as the Son of Man (God in the flesh). PHILLIPPIANS 2:5 "In your relationships with one another, have the same mindset as Christ Jesus: 6 Who, being in very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be used to his own advantage; 7 rather, he made himself nothing by taking the very nature of a servant, being made in human likeness. 8 And being found in appearance as a man, he humbled himself by becoming obedient to death— even death on a cross! 9 Therefore God exalted him to the highest place and gave him the name that is above every name 10 that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, in heaven and on earth and under the earth,11 and every tongue acknowledge that Jesus Christ is Lord,to the glory of God the Father." In that body, all the will of God would be done for Jesus to be our perfect substitute. God sends His Holy Spirit into our hearts through the Gospel message of sins forgiven completed by the vicarious work of Jesus Christ to show how good and acceptable and perfect His will is, so that in the ages to come, it is incontestable and the standard for God's judgement for all people when He returns to judge all mankind. The Holy Spirit comes to us to guide us in the steps of the Master, so that we do not have to be slaves to sin. (Romans 12:1-2; Acts 1:1-4; 2 Peter 1:2-4) God, the Father of spirits (Hebrews 12:9), who knew us before the foundation of the world, gave us a body. His purpose is that we should follow in Jesus’ footsteps so that God’s will be done on earth as it is in heaven. “Always carrying about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus. Christ died on the cross of Calvary as payment for the penalty of sin that we had coming but He also led a perfect life in our behalf, never sinning, which task He fulfilled while He lived on earth as a human being. (2 Timothy 2:11; 2 Corinthians 4:10; Philippians 3:10; Romans 8:3) Sin is anything that goes against God’s will and His laws. To commit sin is to transgress or disobey these laws. The lust to sin dwells in human nature. In other words, it is contaminated and motivated by the sinful tendencies that dwell in all people as a result of the fall into sin and disobedience in the garden of Eden. In these bodies, we also have a sinful human nature, which has a will of its own that is in conflict with the will of God. So our spirit has to fight. Almost all talk of battles and wars when concerning a Christian life refers to the inner battle that arises when a sinful thought tempts you. God’s Spirit, living in the hearts of believers, and the flesh are at odds. See James 1:14. Also called “sin in the flesh.” Things that go on around us have an effect on us, and we are tempted. Thoughts that are not from God, and that would draw us away from our connection with Him try to enter in. (James 1:14-15). As sinners, we often fail but believers are "forgiven sinners" because Jesus carried the punishment for all mankind's sins. There is no time to mess around, wasting our time in doing our own will. We are here to do God’s will, and to do that we need to be extremely humble, acknowledge our weaknesses as human beings, and go to the throne of grace with repentant hearts seeking HIs forgiveness, which He richly provides. HEBREWS 4:18 “Let us therefore come boldly to the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy and find grace to help in time of need.” Because Jesus was tempted, yet did not sin, it is possible for us to come to Him with boldness to receive forgiveness and grace, and the Spirit's power where we get the help we need to overcome sin, as God intended and promised. “And we know that all things work together for good to those who love God, to those who are the called according to His purpose.” (Romans 8:28) We were foreknown and predestined to be conformed to the image of Jesus. (Romans 8:29-30) God’s desire for us is that we gain divine nature, which is eternal life. [Excerpt] The body of Christ is made up of all of those who have been blessed by the Holy Spirit. They work in the ministry that He has appointed them, which differs from person to person, for the edification of themselves and others to bring all to unity. It is made up of all believers in Christ. Many people use the words "Body of Christ" or "Christ's Church on Earth" to describe a certain denomination or group or even the physical building that Christians gather in. The Bible makes it clear that the true church of Christ is made up of all those who trust in Jesus for the forgiveness of their sins and His resurrection that, one day, they too will experience. All of this is to God's glory both on earth and for all eternity. This is the very reason that He formed us so fearfully and wonderfully.

Where is the destination? We should first ask ‘what is the purpose of life?’ What is the value of life if we do not know the purpose of that life? It is the greatest good for an individual to discuss virtue every day...for the un-examined life is not worth living – Socrates Our life on earth is a very short period compared to the universe time scale; It could be a temporary test period. There are many verses in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam to teach that God has created everything in heavens and earth. God has empowered each of us to be happy and blessed. God has enabled people to choose their own destinations. God does not predetermine plans for us. Existential crisis is when one suddenly realizes that one finds no obvious purpose, reason for one’s existence. Sooner or later we all come to this crisis, which revelation has become like a “plague” in our generation, showing itself through the symptoms of emptiness, depression, suicidal tendencies, increasing substance abuse, escapism to “shop till drop” mentality, etc. As Human beings we cannot satisfy ourselves by simply, blindly fulfilling our instinctive and social desires for food, sex, family, wealth, power and knowledge. Nature’s evolution demands - and this is also imprinted into our DNA - to start searching for a “higher meaning”: researching and revealing our unique Human role, purpose in Nature’s perfect, fully integrated system. The innate call towards this starts with the “existential crisis”, with the irrepressible question about “meaning of life” pushing us towards finding answers. The previous two answers by Kieran and Alexander are beautiful answers. Brief and perfectly to the point. Any time I compare the image I have of myself to the image I have of how another person views me in comparison to his or her self, I experience an existential crisis. The higher the pedestal I put that other person on the more intense my existential crisis. Hegel talks about this in his “Phenomenology of the spirit” Phenomenology of Spirit, Chapter 4: “Self-consciousness” Sartre said it best when he said, “ Hell is other people.” Observe how in comparing yourself you constantly isolate yourself and thus you suffer. Being conscious of a constant need for some kind of self validation from others and the “angst” that results from it is the main point of Hegels “Phenomenology the Spirit” and Sartre’s “No Exit.” Sartre: Hell is other people (Explanation)

An existential crisis is when your paradigms about the meaning of your existence break down. The assumptions you made about what helps you thrive in the world, no longer hold true. The existential crisis is the dark void between the rupture of your previous paradigms and the generation of new insights into the value and meaning of your own life. Long held beliefs are psychologically painful to let go, which is what can cause the experience to be disconcerting. If you are in one, embrace it. It’s an unpleasant period, but it can be one of the most transformative experiences in your life. We are not comfortable sitting in the dark, but if you persevere, and use this opportunity to rethink and process your emotions and thoughts you will find a better light.

I'm going through a very difficult one right now, I guess. Every morning I wake up, extremely tired after 7 hours of sleep, only to question my reasons to getting out of bed. At that moment, all my commitments seem valueless, non important. Day after day, I feel more bitter and lonely. Despite I am married, this loneliness grows disproportionately. And it is completely my fault, by the way. I find my job senseless and I began hating it. There is no purpose in it from the way I see it. A year ago, I moved to Spain and since that moment, I have made zero friends. No one to visit and chat during weekends. And while everything seems to be failing apart in my head, financial challenges spawn everywhere, jeopardizing our wellbeing. Now, this may be considered as an existencial crisis. I haven't been able of overcome it yet, so I cannot speak about a positive point of view. Nevertheless, I continue believing that everything is going to be better, that this isn't the rest of my life. I really hope so.

There is no one way to answer this because truth is relative. This means truth depends on the individual, if we define truth as “the way things really are.” It seems not too many existentialists ask themselves whether the depression/anxiety comes first or second regarding existential crisis. Does temperament (nature), upbringing (“good enough” parenting or nurture), avoiding trauma and other problems growing up, have anything to do with whether or not a person will have a “need” to deal with an existential crisis? What are the factors? Why do some gravitate towards Freud (the animal instinct) or Jung (the symbolic person)? Why is meaninglessness a far bigger problem those struggling with a personality disorder? The existentialists are absolutely correct, as are the Buddhists. Life presents us all with inescapable forms of potentially acute suffering: growing old, getting sick, losing others, coping with isolation, meaninglessness, death and freedom. Being at peace with the human condition is highly recommended. Saying “of course” is a far better option than shelling out the money for more plastic surgery. But why does one person have “attacks” of death anxiety while another simply accepts death and doesn’t have much fear of it at all? Does the latter have better defense mechanisms, therefore better able to repress/suppress death anxiety than the existential traveler? Nietzsche observed we become what we focus on (the abyss problem). Is the self-analysis and inner thinking involved in existentialism too much of a good thing? (e.g. eventually creates depression and meaninglessness etc.). Is there such as thing as Existentialist OCD? If so, which writers have it and which don’t? How does PTSD fit into it all? People with this problem have acutely charged antennae which constantly scrutinize the environment for clues, signs and evidence of imminent danger, at the exclusion of the opposite. A proffessional athlete who suffers a career ending injury can go through an existential crisis. An existential crisis can occur anytime somebody identifies fully in some sort of role and then that role is suddenly taken away or that role becomes less appealing for whatever reason. That leaves the person on unstable ground. They feel that they no longer know who they are, what’s expected of them and where they are going. They don’t know why they exist anymore and this is what we call an existential crisis. I had one of those, probably many in my 40 years. My experience encouraged me to identify with the unidentifiable.

An existential crisis is a moment at which an individual questions if their life has meaning, purpose, or value. It may be commonly, but not necessarily, tied to depression or inevitably negative speculations on purpose in life (e.g., "if one day I will be forgotten, what is the point of all of my work?")
